Each local dataset, ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}, comprises a number of sample data with input-output pairings as follows: {ğ±i,d(k),yi(k)}i=1Dksubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ·ğ‘˜ğ‘–1\{\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)},y_{i}^{(k)}\}^{D_{k}}_{i=1}, where ğ±i,d(k)âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is an input with dğ‘‘d features, and yi(k)âˆˆâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘˜â„y_{i}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R} is the accompanying class-labeled output. Each device behaves differently based on its activities, generating different sizes of local data; thus, ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} is non-i.i.d. and unbalanced. As previously stated, the connections between the devices and the server are made via an unreliable wireless link. Also, the devices themselves are resource-constrained, posing the challenge of scheduling and selecting participants in order to improve the convergence speed and minimize training time, particularly for CFL, where the main objective is to train a set of models rather than a single model as in conventional training. For the readerâ€™s convenience, the main symbols utilized in this work are listed in TableÂ I.

references: In all experiments, we use a bandwidth of B=10ğµ10B=10 MHz, with each sub-channel having a bandwidth of 111 MHz. The channel gain of each device, hrksubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿh^{k}_{r}, is randomly modeled with a path loss (Î±=g0â€‹(d0d)4ğ›¼subscriptğ‘”0superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘0ğ‘‘4\alpha=g_{0}(\frac{d_{0}}{d})^{4}) , where g0=âˆ’35subscriptğ‘”035g_{0}=-35 dB and the baseline distance d0=2subscriptğ‘‘02d_{0}=2 m. We assume that the distances between the devices and the coordinating server are uniformly distributed between 202020 and 100100100 m. In addition, the power of AWGN is defined as N0=10âˆ’6subscriptğ‘0superscript106N_{0}=10^{-6}watts. The transmission power Prksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘ŸP^{k}_{r} is distributed at random between pmâ€‹iâ€‹n=âˆ’10subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›10p_{min}=-10 dBm and pmâ€‹aâ€‹x=20subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥20p_{max}=20 dBm. The deviceâ€™s CPU frequency fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k} is generated randomly between 111 GHz and 999 GHz, and the required CPU cycles per data point, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, is set to 202020 and it is assumed to be homogeneous for all devices. We use two federated datasets, FEMNIST and CIFAR-10Â [45], for handwriting classification and object recognition, respectively. Specifically, FEMNIST is utilized for handwriting classifications of both letters and digits (A-Z, a-z, and 0-9), and it has 305,654, 28 x 28, images while CIFAR-10 consists of 60,000 32x32 colored images. We split both datasets for each device into 80% for training and 2% for testing. Further, we utilize both datasets in a non-i.i.d. manner, whereas we split each dataset into â„â„\mathcal{I} fragments, and then we assign each device only two random classes. For the model architecture, the convolutional neural network (CNN) classifier is adopted for FEMNIST, and Alexnetâ€”a deep neural network (DNN) is adopted for CIFAR-10. In our models, we employed 2 hidden layers in the FEMNIST model and 13 hidden layers in the CIFAR-10 model. For both learning tasks, we utilized the ReLU activation function for the hidden layers and the Softmax activation function for the output layer. To simplify the presentation, we list all simulation parameters in Table II.

references:
Now, we present the results of the testing accuracy, focusing on the fairness between clients.
We note that the training procedure for both all the algorithms, the proposed and benchmarks, has produced multiple models based on clustering, including a conventional FEEL model and a more tailored model for every group, as depicted in Table III. We test all models amongst 151515 clients after finishing all the training rounds to show the effectiveness of each model depending on the resulting accuracy. One can see that our proposed approach yields three better-tailored models. As shown in Table III(a), it is clear that all participating devices attain well-fitting accuracy (outlined in green color), and inconsistency in performance (maximum accuracy and minimum accuracy in the last row of Table III(a)) across all
is approximately 10%percent1010\% only when our approach is used. In comparison, as depicted in Table III(b), almost more than 1313\frac{1}{3} of the tested participants(i.e., P 1, P 2, P 3, P 4, and P 5) achieve undesired accuracy (outlined in red color). The inconsistency in performance can reach up to 31.4%percent31.431.4\%, demonstrating that some resulted models are still biased to the repeatedly selected devices which dominate the clustering.

S7.T3.st1.table:

references:
The study of FL deployment via edge networks from various perspectives has gained a lot of interest in the literature.
A decentralized stochastic gradient descent approach was studied inÂ [31] considering the context of a bandwidth limit in several channel conditions, where every client is chosen opportunistically for transmission according to its channel state.
Earlier works considered perfect updates-upload tasks to address the delay aspectsâ€™ challenges in FEEL. Yet, the impacts of wireless channels are ignored, especially the ability to leverage the characteristics of the channels (e.g., fading, multi-access, and broadcasting) to reduce the latency. Therefore, the broadband analogue aggregation technique is fine-tuned for probabilistic channels due to restricted radio spectrum, particularly channel capacity [31].
To be more precise, prior to transmitting the models, the edge devices assess the sparsity of the gradients and then transfer them to a lower-dimensional realm constrained by the limited channel capacity. In addition, the works in [32] investigated the convergence of the FL algorithm across wireless links, taking into account the effect of unstable connections on the global model convergence.

As Fig.Â 1 depicts, this work considers a set of ğ’¦={1,â€¦,K}ğ’¦1â€¦ğ¾\mathcal{K}=\{1,\dots,K\} heterogeneous edge devices, K=|ğ’¦|ğ¾ğ’¦K=|\mathcal{K}|, associated with and coordinated by an edge server via a base station (BS). Each individual kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K} device owns a local dataset ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}, with Dk=|ğ’Ÿk|subscriptğ·ğ‘˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜D_{k}=|\mathcal{D}_{k}| number of samples, and the total number of samples amongst all devices is D=âˆ‘k=1KDkğ·superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ·ğ‘˜D=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{D_{k}}. Each local dataset, ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}, comprises a number of sample data with input-output pairings as follows: {ğ±i,d(k),yi(k)}i=1Dksubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ·ğ‘˜ğ‘–1\{\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)},y_{i}^{(k)}\}^{D_{k}}_{i=1}, where ğ±i,d(k)âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}_{i,d}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is an input with dğ‘‘d features, and yi(k)âˆˆâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘˜â„y_{i}^{(k)}\in\mathbb{R} is the accompanying class-labeled output. Each device behaves differently based on its activities, generating different sizes of local data; thus, ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} is non-i.i.d. and unbalanced. As previously stated, the connections between the devices and the server are made via an unreliable wireless link. Also, the devices themselves are resource-constrained, posing the challenge of scheduling and selecting participants in order to improve the convergence speed and minimize training time, particularly for CFL, where the main objective is to train a set of models rather than a single model as in conventional training. For the readerâ€™s convenience, the main symbols utilized in this work are listed in TableÂ I.

It is worth highlighting that the server is anticipated to have considerably more computing capabilities than the clients; therefore, the computation cost on the server side is negligible.
We can see that there is a trade-off in the scheduling problem between the number of participants chosen in a given round and the entire number of rounds, which could be handled by Trsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ŸT_{r}. Assuming we started with a short Trsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ŸT_{r}, the number of engaging participants in Î©rsubscriptÎ©ğ‘Ÿ\Omega_{r} can decrease, which is unsuitable for CFL leading to slowly partitioning the clients into congruent groups. This brings out unwanted communication costs due to increasing the number of training rounds needed to converge. Hence, we propose to initiate a long Trsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ŸT_{r} at the beginning of the training; then, this time is reduced as the correct clustering is performed where only the best clients that require less latency will be selected from the cluster reaching the stopping point as follows:

In all experiments, we use a bandwidth of B=10ğµ10B=10 MHz, with each sub-channel having a bandwidth of 111 MHz. The channel gain of each device, hrksubscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿh^{k}_{r}, is randomly modeled with a path loss (Î±=g0â€‹(d0d)4ğ›¼subscriptğ‘”0superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘0ğ‘‘4\alpha=g_{0}(\frac{d_{0}}{d})^{4}) , where g0=âˆ’35subscriptğ‘”035g_{0}=-35 dB and the baseline distance d0=2subscriptğ‘‘02d_{0}=2 m. We assume that the distances between the devices and the coordinating server are uniformly distributed between 202020 and 100100100 m. In addition, the power of AWGN is defined as N0=10âˆ’6subscriptğ‘0superscript106N_{0}=10^{-6}watts. The transmission power Prksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘ŸP^{k}_{r} is distributed at random between pmâ€‹iâ€‹n=âˆ’10subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›10p_{min}=-10 dBm and pmâ€‹aâ€‹x=20subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥20p_{max}=20 dBm. The deviceâ€™s CPU frequency fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k} is generated randomly between 111 GHz and 999 GHz, and the required CPU cycles per data point, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, is set to 202020 and it is assumed to be homogeneous for all devices. We use two federated datasets, FEMNIST and CIFAR-10Â [45], for handwriting classification and object recognition, respectively. Specifically, FEMNIST is utilized for handwriting classifications of both letters and digits (A-Z, a-z, and 0-9), and it has 305,654, 28 x 28, images while CIFAR-10 consists of 60,000 32x32 colored images. We split both datasets for each device into 80% for training and 2% for testing. Further, we utilize both datasets in a non-i.i.d. manner, whereas we split each dataset into â„â„\mathcal{I} fragments, and then we assign each device only two random classes. For the model architecture, the convolutional neural network (CNN) classifier is adopted for FEMNIST, and Alexnetâ€”a deep neural network (DNN) is adopted for CIFAR-10. In our models, we employed 2 hidden layers in the FEMNIST model and 13 hidden layers in the CIFAR-10 model. For both learning tasks, we utilized the ReLU activation function for the hidden layers and the Softmax activation function for the output layer. To simplify the presentation, we list all simulation parameters in Table II.

Maximum number of data points: In this algorithm, the coordinating server chooses the participants having the largest data sizes and keeps connecting with them until the end of the training. We also extend this approach to select the maximum number of data examples amongst clients every round, assuming that the channel of each participant is not stable and diverse participants may be involved in different rounds.

Now, we present the results of the testing accuracy, focusing on the fairness between clients.
We note that the training procedure for both all the algorithms, the proposed and benchmarks, has produced multiple models based on clustering, including a conventional FEEL model and a more tailored model for every group, as depicted in Table III. We test all models amongst 151515 clients after finishing all the training rounds to show the effectiveness of each model depending on the resulting accuracy. One can see that our proposed approach yields three better-tailored models. As shown in Table III(a), it is clear that all participating devices attain well-fitting accuracy (outlined in green color), and inconsistency in performance (maximum accuracy and minimum accuracy in the last row of Table III(a)) across all
is approximately 10%percent1010\% only when our approach is used. In comparison, as depicted in Table III(b), almost more than 1313\frac{1}{3} of the tested participants(i.e., P 1, P 2, P 3, P 4, and P 5) achieve undesired accuracy (outlined in red color). The inconsistency in performance can reach up to 31.4%percent31.431.4\%, demonstrating that some resulted models are still biased to the repeatedly selected devices which dominate the clustering.

Furthermore, to validate the proposed algorithms, we perform other simulation experiments using the CIFAR-10 dataset as a complex learning task under non-i.i.d. federated settings. This assists in generalizing the performance of the proposed algorithms for different application domains. Figs.Â 5(a), 5(b), 5(c) andÂ 5(d) show the minimum, maximum, and average testing accuracy amongst clients where the minimum accuracy represents the lowest accuracy can be achieved by the client and vise versa. It is worth mentioning that the proposed approach balances the accuracy between all clients despite the number of participating clients where the gap between the maximum and minimum accuracy amongst clients reaches up to 10%percent1010\%, meaning that the resulting models optimally fit all local data distribution. At the same time, we notice that the best channel, the best l2-norm, and the max-samples approaches increase the accuracy gap between the clients, reaching up to 70%percent7070\%, especially if the number of clients increases. This stems from the fact that the server stays connected with the same clients during all global rounds in those approaches, particularly when the channel is not changing rapidly, leading to biased models that can only fit the participantsâ€™ clients. In addition, random scheduling provides less accuracy gaps due to the randomness of participant selection. Nevertheless, the proposed scheduling approach substantially outperforms all benchmarks and provides much more stable accuracy regardless of the distribution of the data and the number of clients in the network.

The deviceâ€™s CPU frequency fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k} is generated randomly between 111 GHz and 999 GHz, and the required CPU cycles per data point, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, is set to 202020 and it is assumed to be homogeneous for all devices. We use two federated datasets, FEMNIST and CIFAR-10Â [45], for handwriting classification and object recognition, respectively. Specifically, FEMNIST is utilized for handwriting classifications of both letters and digits (A-Z, a-z, and 0-9), and it has 305,654, 28 x 28, images while CIFAR-10 consists of 60,000 32x32 colored images. We split both datasets for each device into 80% for training and 2% for testing. Further, we utilize both datasets in a non-i.i.d. manner, whereas we split each dataset into â„â„\mathcal{I} fragments, and then we assign each device only two random classes. For the model architecture, the convolutional neural network (CNN) classifier is adopted for FEMNIST, and Alexnetâ€”a deep neural network (DNN) is adopted for CIFAR-10. In our models, we employed 2 hidden layers in the FEMNIST model and 13 hidden layers in the CIFAR-10 model. For both learning tasks, we utilized the ReLU activation function for the hidden layers and the Softmax activation function for the output layer. To simplify the presentation, we list all simulation parameters in Table II.

Maximum number of data points: In this algorithm, the coordinating server chooses the participants having the largest data sizes and keeps connecting with them until the end of the training. We also extend this approach to select the maximum number of data examples amongst clients every round, assuming that the channel of each participant is not stable and diverse participants may be involved in different rounds.

Now, we present the results of the testing accuracy, focusing on the fairness between clients.
We note that the training procedure for both all the algorithms, the proposed and benchmarks, has produced multiple models based on clustering, including a conventional FEEL model and a more tailored model for every group, as depicted in Table III. We test all models amongst 151515 clients after finishing all the training rounds to show the effectiveness of each model depending on the resulting accuracy. One can see that our proposed approach yields three better-tailored models. As shown in Table III(a), it is clear that all participating devices attain well-fitting accuracy (outlined in green color), and inconsistency in performance (maximum accuracy and minimum accuracy in the last row of Table III(a)) across all
is approximately 10%percent1010\% only when our approach is used. In comparison, as depicted in Table III(b), almost more than 1313\frac{1}{3} of the tested participants(i.e., P 1, P 2, P 3, P 4, and P 5) achieve undesired accuracy (outlined in red color). The inconsistency in performance can reach up to 31.4%percent31.431.4\%, demonstrating that some resulted models are still biased to the repeatedly selected devices which dominate the clustering.

Furthermore, to validate the proposed algorithms, we perform other simulation experiments using the CIFAR-10 dataset as a complex learning task under non-i.i.d. federated settings. This assists in generalizing the performance of the proposed algorithms for different application domains. Figs.Â 5(a), 5(b), 5(c) andÂ 5(d) show the minimum, maximum, and average testing accuracy amongst clients where the minimum accuracy represents the lowest accuracy can be achieved by the client and vise versa. It is worth mentioning that the proposed approach balances the accuracy between all clients despite the number of participating clients where the gap between the maximum and minimum accuracy amongst clients reaches up to 10%percent1010\%, meaning that the resulting models optimally fit all local data distribution. At the same time, we notice that the best channel, the best l2-norm, and the max-samples approaches increase the accuracy gap between the clients, reaching up to 70%percent7070\%, especially if the number of clients increases. This stems from the fact that the server stays connected with the same clients during all global rounds in those approaches, particularly when the channel is not changing rapidly, leading to biased models that can only fit the participantsâ€™ clients. In addition, random scheduling provides less accuracy gaps due to the randomness of participant selection. Nevertheless, the proposed scheduling approach substantially outperforms all benchmarks and provides much more stable accuracy regardless of the distribution of the data and the number of clients in the network.
